ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question about the readings: I did the readings the first few classes but realized pretty quickly that the professor largely covered the material during lecture and it didn't add any additional depth to my learning. While the pace of the course was very slow, I saw it as a meditation and perhaps for the type of material discussed this might have been the best approach. However, it was challenging to sit for 3 hour lectures. But I know that I learned things and the pace may have been beneficial to retain imagery--to better imagine some of the land practices that were being described. The professor did seem to struggle some when students would bring up counter-arguments to the material he was presenting, like he took it personally rather than being able to see it as an idea.
This is a great class! Keep it coming!

Great class! A very important perspective for anyone thinking of working in the tropics on forestry issues, or even for those considering forestry in the temperate areas. Really gets at the root of why and how some folks are able to live sustainably from a resource base, as opposed to the dominant industrial society. Thanks!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Identifying and analyzing different indigenous silvicultural systems with an instructor who has on-the-ground experience.

Chuck is so knowledgeable and happy to be talking about these questions. I really enjoyed his lectures and the richness of experience he brought to the class. It felt very practical but still had a conceptual framework to it.

Great examples were provided. The material was really interesting, a different perspective than we normally hear at FES--especially to have an entire class on the topic. The professor had a lot of passion for the subject that came through clearly.
Chuck's wealth of personal and specialized knowledge on the subject matter.
Great lectures, instructor has a wealth of information about the subject
The perspective of this course changes the way you look at silviculture. It really advances students understanding of social forestry and captures the complexity of indigenous silviculture.
This was a good overview of indigenous silviculture - the practices, management goals, and techniques - which is a very rare and needed area of study at FES.
Dr. Peters' wealth of experience and the perspective he's gained from his travels. Course readings are well-selected and interesting.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: There is a strong emphasis on Southeast Asia as opposed to other regions.

My only complaint would be that a few questions on the midterm were a little to focused on memorizing all the specific examples we learned in class, but most of the questions and the final were more focused on analysis and synthesis, which I appreciated.

Would be nice to have readings that add something different from the lectures...also there wasn't incentive to do the readings because we didn't discuss them. It seems like the course could have covered a lot more material...the readings were thin
Needs to be a more participatory class; less lecture-heavy.
Field trip will improve understanding on techniques of indigenous silviculture
The format of the course (3 hours of lecture) is rather taxing.
I would have liked the class to go into more depth with the case studies. The facts about the breadth of cases were very interesting, but I would have liked to dive into more (e.g., 20 minutes).

Could be more connection between the readings and discussion. The one time we had a discussion was great - Dr. Peters asks tough questions and could facilitate more discussion about the ideas presented in class. A field component would be a useful addition. It felt a little like Dr. Peters was trying to sell us on the fact that indigenous systems are excellent adaptations to their circumstances, which is something that I already bought into and understood. I would have liked more of the class to get into the literature and go deeper into the subject.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: there was no discussion section..
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in tropical forest management, so a class on local management practices is very useful.
It serves my interest as a professional in indigenous forestry/agroforestry

I think the comparison of conventional silviculture and indigenous silviculture is incredibly useful. Students seeking careers as foresters should be required to take this course to gain a more holistic understanding.
I focus on agroforestry, tenure, and landscape scale management - this course touched on all of those areas, and it was a great complement/foundation for my studies.

I plan on practicing forest management in the states and possibly community forestry abroad. This is an extremely useful addition to my courses at Yale. I conducted research at Yale which was relevant to this course - I gained a functional framework of indigenous management from the course which will assist me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn about indigenous systems in developing countries, something not often taught in graduate programs.
It is one of the few courses that looks at forestry practices at FES that doesn't just look at large-scale forestry but how most forest communities actually manage and use their forest resources.
it relates to my job as an agroforestry facilitator.
General interest in indigeneity & knowledges and practices that receive less attention in academia
Fit my research goals and looked interesting.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Definitely. Great course.
Yes
Yes, it give me more knowledge on many kinds of indigenous silvicultural techniques I didn't know previously.
Yes.
Almost, I think we could have gone a little deeper.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend this course to all students, not just foresters. No extensive background in silviculture is necessary, although it is helpful to have a basic understanding of the concepts. Chuck is an expert on the subject and provides useful information. The pace of the course is a little slower and the workload is not very steep.
Definitely take it! Chuck is great and the course was wonderful. I wasn't even planning on taking another course, but I added this on because I could not miss it.

Sign up for a meditation. The material is interesting and the topic is great, but it is slow. Additionally, take caution in bringing in ideas that might be perceived as critical. The professor will likely not receive them well and he may choose to penalize you personally for it.
The course is very interesting, and one of a kind as far as I know (both at FES and in the country, potentially.) It is lecture-heavy, but you'll learn a lot.
This course is accessible to those from different disciplines - not only forestry or ecology backgrounds.

Do it! Even if you don't work in the tropics you'll gain an important perspective onto how many people across the globe carry on in a sustainable manner. This is something we can learn from and use in our own lives.
